title: How much crude oil will Libya produce in September 2017?
preds:
Flipping forecast on the basis that the output data produced by Reuters and OPEC has had a maximum difference of +/- 32tb/d in 2017. 
Libya is at 0.93 mb/d (granted this figure is rounded), adding the maximum difference of 32,000b to this won't take it past the first bracket. 
(https://uk.reuters.com/article/opec-oil/table-opec-oil-output-rises-by-50000-bpd-in-september-reuters-survey-idUKL8N1MA38C)
Thanks @Raisinville for the article.

Production up to 950,000 b/d but clearly this isn't a perfect measure. There could be a lot of variation in the outcome, but I still think it's more likely that it'll fall below the mark based on the available information.

Taking into account some valid points well made by @AB747, as well as @dsarin, who previously (and correctly)  described the media reports as being all over the place, I've made some assumptions for the purpose of constructing a model: (I find the models help me mitigate the effects of my propensity to form an anchor bias early on.) 1) El Sharara field was down for the first 5 days of September: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-06/biggest-libyan-oil-field-expected-to-reopen-wednesday-after-deal 2) On September 6, it started pumping at a rate of 180,000 BPD: https://www.reuters.com/article/libya-oil/update-1-libyas-sharara-oilfield-pumping-only-180000-bpd-workers-idUSL5N1LV5YS?rpc=401&   3) By September 26, total output was 950,000 BPD. (My assumption: This was the 26 day average of total output, not just the output on the 26th.)   Output from El Sharara had reached 230,000 BPD by the 26th.  (My assumption, output had gradually increased from 180,000 BPD on the 6th  to 230,000 BPD by the 26th) https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-27/libya-oil-output-gains-as-country-faces-calls-to-join-opec-cuts 4) El Sharara continues to increase production from 230,000 BPD to 283,000 BPD over the last 4 days of Sept. (My assumption.) Final answer: 962,750 BPD for September.   That takes me right back to 'coin flipping' range.  And again, thanks to @AB747 and @dsarin for comments that prodded me to change some assumptions I had made just a couple of days ago.

Thanks @The_Gnome for the article. 
Been trying to figure out which way to adjust based on this, @WhatCouldHappen made an excellent comment (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/584288) In April 2017, Bloomberg reported on April 10 that Sharara oil field had shut down due to a militant blockade. The article stated production from the oil field was at 200,000b/d and total production was 700,000b/d. (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-10/libya-biggest-oil-field-said-to-shut-for-2nd-time-in-two-weeks)
Bloomberg then reported on April 27 that the field had reopened and Libya’s total production was 491,000 b/d. (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-27/libya-s-biggest-oil-field-said-to-reopen-as-refinery-back-on)
According to OPEC secondary data, in April production was 552 tb/d, whereas in May, production had increased to 730tb/d. Between April and July, Libya has added more than 127tb/d each month. (http://www.opec.org/opec_web/static_files_project/media/downloads/publications/MOMR%20July%202017.pdf)
Libya only needs to add 77.33 tb/d to the August data to reach 967.33tb/d. 
Given that production at Sharara resumed on September 6th, and no outages since then, I think its still possible that they could increase production to (+)967.33tb/d.

Thanks to @The_Gnome for the bloomberg article.   The article is pretty vague about when production came back to 283k at El Sharara.  If it just came back yesterday, then there is a very high probability total production couldn't reach 967k.  If it came back 4 days ago, there's a decent chance it could exceed 967k, if they were able to increase production at all the other fields by, say 5%. I'd say it's no longer a coin flip, but it's not a done deal, either.

Found on twitter:
#Libya || Armed groups threaten to close Sharara Oil Field after 48 hours if Rada force in Tripoli not released activists from Ubari      https://twitter.com/search?src=typd&q=sharara%20oil I don't see anything about it on Reuters or anywhere else.

Revising my forecast - I had made a calculation mistake in the earlier forecast. August production for Libya was 890 kbpd - but that was with Sharara field being operational for a little over half the month. For September, the field has become operational by around 10-11 Sep - so production will be higher than last month, but not by much.

Here's another possibly true, probably misleading story: "Libya's national oil production stands at about 900,000 barrels per day (bpd), down from about 1 million bpd in recent months, a Libyan oil source said on Friday [Today]." http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/libyas-oil-production-at-around-900000-bpd-source/articleshow/60794246.cms
@Dsarin is tracking this one closely, I'm following his lead.

Libya’s Sharara oilfield is producing about 180,000 barrels per day (bpd), 100,000 bpd below recent levels, because of security problems, two workers at the field said on Thursday. http://www.libyabizinfo.com/story-z14023440
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Due to the first 6 or so days of the month having 3 fields shut down and reduced capacity at El Sharara after their reopenings, I find it hard to expect production to much outpace August production if it were to at all. Reports of production levels could be incorrect, or fuzzier than I interpreted, which could be problematic for my prediction. However my number crunching suggests that if production is as reduced as is being widely reported, then the rest of the month would have to have higher levels than July production in order to make up the difference.

Thanks to @wadi79 for this report: https://in.reuters.com/article/libya-oil/update-1-libyas-sharara-oilfield-pumping-only-180000-bpd-workers-idINL5N1LV5YS The key variables seem to be 1) How long will the Sharara field be held to 180,000 BPD, and 2) How much extra capacity is available at the other NOC facilities.   When you take in to account the 5 days (at minimum) the Sharara field was down at the beginning of the month, and the continuing reduction through today, and you assume capacity increases at all the other fields by 5% per month since July, you're looking at a total monthly yield of 986,159 BPD. (At least, according to my spreadsheet.)  And that number drops by 3,333 BPD every day the Sharara field is limited to 180K.  (I use the 5% figure as it coincides with the NOC's goal of hitting 1.3M BPD by the end of the year, so I assumed that as my top end.) If the increased capacity of the other NOC fields doesn't grow by at least 3% per month, it's already too late to hit 967,330 BPD. (Again, per my spreadsheet) Of course, every thing rests on the accuracy of the media reports so if I'm wrong, blame them because my spreadsheets are never wrong.  (Well...if by 'never wrong' you mean 'quite frequently'.)  As always, I look forward to thoughtful opposing views.

August oil production for Libya was 890 kbpd (oil market report). Sharara oil field got back into production on 6 Sep, but is currently producing at 180 kbpd, instead of 270 kbpd. 
https://in.reuters.com/article/libya-oil/update-1-libyas-sharara-oilfield-pumping-only-180000-bpd-workers-idINL5N1LV5YS If Sharara produces at 180 kbpd for rest of the month, then September figure will be 1,025 kbpd.  If Sharara produces 180 kpbd for just 2 weeks, and assuming no other production outages elsewhere, then September figure will be 980 kpbd, above the 967 figure.  If the field produces at 270 kbpd for the second half of the month, the September figure will be 1,070 kbpd - so possibility of exceeding 1093 is really low.
Libya's largest oil field resumed production in August, should easily surpass July numbers over 1000
The oil crescent is thriving since the recent hurricane in the Us
Thanks to @AB747 for finding solid numbers.  Making adjustments based on those numbers.

Following their gradual increase during 2017 967-1093 is the most likely outcome with slight chance for less and next to no chance for more-it is hard to dramatically increase production in a month...
Mostly agree w/ @AB747. Might be a little more optimistic.

OPEC’s September MOMR states Libyan output for August was 890 tb/d, compared to 1,003tb/d in July - based on secondary sources. (http://www.opec.org/opec_web/static_files_project/media/downloads/publications/MOMR%20September%202017.pdf) 
Reports seem to claim production is back to normal. I think it will be possible for Libya to increase output back to the July level, though I'm not sure of their capacity limit. The production target was between 1,000 - 1,300tb/d by the end of the year, so I think it's unlikely given the recent events, that they will be in the (+)1093.53 tb/d category for September.

Output has been increasing steadily, increasing by 154 to 1001 in July (August report). Two more months at that rate would bring it to 1309. There was some disruption of the oil production in late August, but it is described as being "back to normal" by September 6. Because of the disruption it is unlikely to reach 1309, but some increase over July is likely.
I believe the oil production will follow their predicted usage based on population growth.

https://www.upi.com/Energy-News/2017/09/08/Libyan-oil-production-back-to-normal/5691504875284/
A report from commodity pricing group S&P Global Platts, sent to UPI earlier this week, said Libyan crude oil production fell from July levels of 990,000 barrels per day to 830,000 barrels per day in August because of security issues at three of its key oil fields, including Sharara.
Libyan and Nigerian officials were invited to a late September meeting of a committee monitoring the OPEC-led agreement. According to Platts, the two countries combined are producing 480,000 barrels per day more than in October 2016, the month OPEC uses as a peg for production quotas.
Bullish on increasing production from the Sharara field but it will take longer than the month of September to get back up to 1.1 mbd or higher.
Shifting down a little but staying bullish on growing production.

Likely Libya will be able to add 67,330 barrels to the average 0.9mb/d in August as long as the deal with the militia group upholds. 
"Libyan authorities reopened a valve on the pipeline from the southwestern Sharara field to the Zawiya refinery after they reached a final agreement with a militia group that had closed the link, according to a person familiar with the matter, who asked not to be identified because the information is private." (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-06/biggest-libyan-oil-field-expected-to-reopen-wednesday-after-deal)
Thanks for the link @JoeG - oilprice.com article re: military conflict.

Christopher Johnson‏Verified account @chris1reuters  2h2 hours ago
#Libya lifts force majeure on loadings of #Sharara crude #oil from #Zawiya terminal - document seen by @Reuters 
#OPEC #OOTT #gas #Tripoli
***************
By Aidan Lewis and Ahmad Ghaddar
TUNIS/LONDON, Sept 6 (Reuters) - Oil production at Libya’s Sharara field, the country’s largest, was resuming on Wednesday after a valve was reopened on a pipeline shut by an armed group for more than two weeks, Libyan oil industry sources said.
“We have just started, little by little,” said one source at the field, who asked not to be named. He said it would likely take three to four days for production to reach normal levels.
http://af.reuters.com/article/africaTech/idAFL8N1LN3Q2

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-29/libya-central-bank-issues-revenue-warning-over-oil-disruption "Libya’s central bank said recent disruption had slashed production by around 350,000 barrels a day, while unrest and shutdowns over the past three years have cost the OPEC member more than $160 billion in direct and indirect losses." http://oilprice.com/Energy/Crude-Oil/Are-Libyan-Oil-Production-Gains-History.html "Libya’s production increases, which have been questioned by insiders, have proven to be unsustainable due to fighting between militias and government forces in oil producing regions. After the shutdown of the Sharara oilfield last week, two other main producing fields have now been hit by armed militias in Libya’s western region. Sources reported that an armed militia from Zintan, directly linked to the heavily armed Petroleum Facilities Guard, which was set up to protect the country’s oil and gas infrastructure, has closed the El Feel and Hamada fields by blocking their respective pipelines. The Petroleum Facilities Guard is also slated to be involved in the Sharara oilfield shutdown." "A military conflict appears to be brewing between the Libyan National Army of General Haftar and the western militias. Egyptian sources have reported that a new military confrontation is expected soon between armed militias and the LNA in the so-called Oil Crescent Area."

Libya exempt from restrictions.  Once pumped 1.6m.  now 1m, but motivated to return to 1.6m.  so. i'm going with an increase from current 1m, slowed only by need for infrastructure and workforce constraints

Most probably the outlook will be much clearer once the August production will be published. An extrapolation from the data of the last three months (an increase of 120-150 tb\d per month) would suggest a production around 1250 for September is not impossible, starting from the 1000 tb\d of July.
However, recent news of a sharp decline in August because of instability (here https://naija247news.com/2017/09/03/crude-oil-price-analysis-for-september-4-2017/ they mention 813 mb\d, other numbers fluctuate below 850) seems to suggest that anything in the last three categories is quite utopic.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Adjusting downward on the basis of the excellent data and analysis by @wadi79

OPEC is sly like a fox.  Since the shale oil boom, OPEC has consistently stated they believe shale oil will dry up sooner than later.  Together, OPEC states are an oil superpower that is experiencing a downturn because of the well-know halving of oil prices.  My belief is OPEC countries are taking turns increasing oil production at around break even prices to bust the shale boom and correct the market to $80-$100 per barrel of crude oil.  It's Libya's turn, but the increase will happen slowly.
Forecast reduced due ton continuing reductions at three oil fields.
Recent news confirming pessimism on the upside.

Revising upwards the possibility of production below 967 kbpd from 25% to 50% following this story:
https://www.reuters.com/article/opec-oil-idUSL8N1LH40Y However, there is still a decent chance that production may stay in between 967-1093 kbdp. More than 1093 is almost impossible, hence 1%.

Production was thought to be about 800 -1000 in July.  A pipeline was blown up this week which will cut 330 from that.  Assuming they get that fixed in a couple of weeks the prospect for exceeding 967 still seems very slim.

Adjusting forecast: Sharara oil field was still closed as of 27 August and production at El Feel (as other forecasters have mentioned) was disrupted and a force majeure was declared last week. 
“Hamada oil field will gradually stop pumping because of the pipeline closing. Force Majeure was declared at Hamada.” 
(https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-27/libya-s-oil-disruptions-widen-as-two-more-fields-halt-output) 
Looking unlikely that Libya will be able to significantly increase production on top of July’s output due to this disruption.

Production will drop in August after fresh disruptions by armed forces. Libya’s biggest field, Sharara, has been shut for about a week after an armed group closed the pipeline that linked the deposit to an export terminal. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-27/libya-s-oil-disruptions-widen-as-two-more-fields-halt-output.  Before July, Libya was averaging way below 960 td/b, hence developments regarding the closures of fields need to be closely monitored throughout September.
On the low end  because of two field shutdown. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-libya-oil-idUSKCN1B70BY

Libya’s crude oil production 
Libya is an OPEC member but was exempt from the production cut deal due to political and economic instability. A Reuters survey estimates that Libya’s crude oil output rose by 180,000 bpd (barrels per day) in July 2017 compared to the previous month. Production is near a four-year high. The EIA (U.S. Energy Information Administration) estimates that Libya’s crude oil production averaged 0.38 MMbpd in 2016. If Libya’s production averages 0.8 MMbpd in 2017, it would offset one-third of the reduced production from OPEC’s production cut deal. An OPEC and non-OPEC monitoring committee meeting was held on July 24, 2017, in Russia. Meeting participants decided to allow Libya to increase production as high as 1.25 MMbpd. Production has risen 60% since January 2017. Libya can ramp up production by 22% from current levels. 
Libya’s oil production has climbed to more than 1 million barrels a day for the first time in four years, further complicating OPEC’s struggle to regain control of the oil market. The North African country is pumping 1.005 million barrels a day, according to a person with direct knowledge of the situation, who asked not to be identified because they aren’t authorized to speak to the media. That would be the highest since June 2013, when Libya pumped 1.13 million barrels a day, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. 
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-02/libya-s-oil-production-said-to-exceed-1-million-barrels-a-day
---------------- 
COMMENTS: Libya can still raise production by 22% from current levels. However, politically instability is still a big factor to consider.

I think the status quo for the next couple months will involve rolling stoppages among different areas, usually due to violence. The other factor could be that hitting the last peak output level will not be so simple due to infrastructure issues and an exodus of expertise.
Take together, the downward pressures appear to be greater than those moving the production higher

Ok, so this seems to hinge on several factors: conflict issues around the Sharara and El-Fil oil fields, plus so far unsuccessful OPEC pressure to cut production, plus Libya's stated goal to ramp production up to 1320+ barrels by the end of this year through partnering with the German oil company Wintershall. So let's look at these 1 by 1: "Sharara (oilfield) recently reached output of 280,000 barrels per day, but closed this week due to a pipeline blockade. Its production is key to Libya’s oil output, which surged above 1-million barrels per day in late June." https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/markets/2017-08-23-price-of-oil-slumps-on-rising-production-in-libya/ Understanding that we are looking at a base of 1001 a day for June/July we need to look at whether OPEC will be successful in forcing a production cut, whether Sharara stays open, and how much Wintershall will be able to help ramp up production.  Sharara has shut down a couple times this year already for time periods from about 2 weeks to about 3 days. Last year it shut down for about 10 months. Looking at  this helped me discover "oil Twitter." The situation here remains volatile & this will have to be followed really every couple of days since it'll be a major factor in which category wins out.  I expect to change my initial prediction here a few times based on the volatility of the local situation there.  OPEC has exempted Libya from cuts, according to Reuters: "Libya has been exempted from an OPEC-led push to cut global production and bolster oil prices, and the recovery of the North African country’s output has complicated the bloc’s efforts to curb supply. But the renewed problems at Sharara show how fragile the gains remain, vulnerable to security challenges, local protests, political splits, and shortfalls in the NOC’s maintenance and investment budget." https://af.reuters.com/article/africaTech/idAFL8N1L8366 So let's see what's up with Wintershall's activity (https://www.wintershall.com/worldwide/libya.html). Now Wintershall & Libya have been at odds over production & payment in the recent past (https://www.ft.com/content/e7eed8f8-35a7-11e7-bce4-9023f8c0fd2e). Nonetheless they seem to have kissed and made up currently. This has caused the Libyan oil chief to predict: “We are able to produce an average of 1.1m to 1.2m [barrels a day] over the rest of this year but for this to happen our oil must flow freely. A national effort is required,” said Mustafa Sanalla, chairman of Libya NOC, in a statement to the Financial Times. "   The Libya Observer seems to have strong daily economic coverage, so that plus oil Twitter looks like the place to be.

https://www.upi.com/Energy-News/2017/08/24/OPEC-All-options-on-the-table-to-ensure-market-balance/5441503579385/
The overall OPEC-led effort faces internal threats from Libya and Nigeria, two strong producers exempt from the agreement because of national security issues....
Meanwhile, the monitoring committee said compliance was 94 percent, lower than in previous months. Ole Hanson, the head of commodity strategy at Saxo Bank, told UPI the deal was working, but rising production from Libya, Nigeria and the United States, "together with reduced compliance, has reduced the positive impact of solid demand growth."
The monitoring committee added it was keen on inviting Libya and Nigeria to the next round of meetings.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-oil-idUSKCN1B303A?il=0
Trying to guess out something like oil production in a country described herein as "still chaotic" is enough to drive me to the bourbon.  (Well, it's not really a drive; more of a putt.)
reversion to the  mean along with historically low demand in September and October.
actual production and reported production to OPEC may be different from leaked (and possibly actual numbers) of around 1mmbpd.  Incentive will be for under-reporting production, so 5% downside.
I'm actually just taking the bottom 3 probabilities (9%) and splitting them between the top two, favoring the higher of the two. Want to see how it goes.
A trial of ISIS members started and this will increase the likelihood of disruptions.

There is a possibility that oil output could fall below 967.33, though I give this a small chance mainly due to the fact that disruptions at oil fields in the last few months have not been prolonged and therefore, would not have a big impact on output data.  Looking at the data and current events, it appears unlikely that Libya will be able to produce more than 1328.41 in the next month, but I will adjust this bracket accordingly when the August production data comes out mid-September. 
The last time Libya was producing more than 1328.41 was in the second quarter of 2013, according to the December 2013 OPEC MOMR. http://www.opec.org/opec_web/static_files_project/media/downloads/publications/MOMR_December_2013.pdf
Plus, as @Dsarin said, the chairman of the LCOG expects oil production will surpass 1mb/d mark by the end of the year. Whereas, the NOC announced plans to raise output to 1.32mb/d by the end of 2017 - these figures would likely be based on best case scenario. (https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/20/business/energy-environment/oil-price-opec-libya.html?_r=0) Disruptions:
“Libya’s NOC declared a force majeure Sunday on crude deliveries from Sharara oil field after a blockage by a militant group on Saturday.”
The Zintan Brigade was responsible for closing the Rayaina pipeline, again. “In April, the Zintan leadership struck what was meant to be a long-lasting deal with the NOC and the PFG, allowing NOC to lift its force majeure. The deal was not published, but according to some sources in Libya it was dependent on three conditions - build hospitals and schools, greater representation for its leader in the government, and allowing internal flights from Zintan. However, none of those conditions have been met as yet” (https://www.platts.com/latest-news/oil/dubai/libyas-noc-declares-force-majeure-at-key-sharara-27865745) 
bloomberg.com later reported the pipeline was closed because the group was seeking the release of one of its members from Tripoli prison, according to a Petroleum Facilities Guard. (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-21/libya-halts-loadings-from-biggest-oil-field-in-latest-disruption)  Also possible disruptions from the Benghazi Defense Brigades (March 2017 - captured al-Sidra, the biggest oil port in Libya, and Ras Lanuf, Libya’s biggest refinery) and Islamic State, amongst other militia groups.
EIA says Libia hit a million b/d in July. State National Oil Corp. Chairman Mustafa Sanalla said in April he wanted to boost national output to 1.1 million barrels a day by August (via Bloomberg).

Wintershall dispute has been settled.  Despite the dispute and brief conflicts and blockades,
Libya NOC was able to increase production and revenues with the goal of  attracting more western investment to reach their goal of 1.8 million next year. The NOC will take advantage of these conditions and increased revenue to stabalize port and political infrastructure.

Libya's oil production doesn't depend on external factors such as OPEC quota (none for them) or oil price (Libya is a low cost producer and can profitably produce at current levels).  The factors, according to me, will be internal - namely, the civil war.  Libya produced 1,001 thousand barrels/day (tbd) in July, 847 tbd in June, 727 tbd in May and 550 in April. Average for Q1-2017 was 656 tbd. Production was low because of the civil war. The civil war is not over - there is a possibility that oil-fields, pipelines or terminals could be hit by one of the belligerents - leading to a drop in production.  If one of the various factions hits oil infrastructure, production could fall. Hence 25% probability for below 967.  The current production or an increase is likely in September, in absence of any disruption, hence 65% for 967-1093.  Increase beyond 1,093 seems less likely in a short span of 2 months.  Every day/week of undisturbed operations means a higher chance for the 967-1093 segment. This number will have to be tracked and updated on a weekly basis.

I think oil exporters are more nervous about the changes in the electric vehicle industry than they let on. They're taking a wait and see approach right now. Plus, everyone is waiting to see if Drumpf does something stupid with US oil exports. Wait and see is the name of the game right now.

‘Recovered Impressively’ “Libyan production has recovered impressively and part of that is certainly that recent disruptions have proved short-lived but I still think it would be wrong to describe the oil sector as stable,” Richard Mallinson, a geopolitical analyst at Energy Aspects Ltd. in London, said Wednesday by email. “There has been plenty of tension with the government in Tripoli as Sanalla’s requests for extra funding for maintenance and to address local issues have largely been ignored.”
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-17/libya-s-getting-better-at-keeping-its-oil-flowing BENGHAZI, Libya (Reuters) - Production at Libya's Sharara oilfield dropped to between 130,000 and 150,000 barrels per day (bpd), from about 280,000 bpd, because of recent security breaches, an engineer who works at the field said on Tuesday

It's difficult to see the top 2 options as a possibility. More capacity will come online, but it can be disrupted for many reasons. Problems with ISIS introduce an element of fragility to distributed and difficult to defend oil infrastructure. Reports of ISIS fighters from Syria/Iraq regrouping in Libya.
Production has rapidly increased in 2017 as there has been some stability. Hard to know if they can maintain rapidity of rise.

“Both Libya and Nigeria appear to have hit a ceiling at current production levels. If anything, there now appears to be more downside than upside to both country’s output over the coming months, which if materialising, will be more bullish for oil prices,” James Davis, head of oil supply at FGE London, told Gulf News.
“Now that further growth does not appear to be likely, and therefore, not necessarily seen as a further threat to global balances, there is less chance that either country will be included in production cuts agreement. However, they may still be given a target level that is above their current output levels that they are not to exceed,” he added.
Echoing similar views, Spencer Welch, director of IHS Energy in London said both countries have made significant production gains in the last couple of months and to get much higher would be a struggle. http://gulfnews.com/business/sectors/energy/further-oil-output-rise-in-nigeria-libya-unlikely-analysts-say-1.2075995
On second thought, it'll grow faster than my first guess.

The good thing about Libyan production is that a lot of the infrastructure is already in place. The bad thing is that the political structure has more or less collapsed and is still recovering. Right now (and presumably in September) most oil producing and exporting regions are in the hands of General Haftar and his Libyan National Army so there is more security than in the past. So I think productions keeps increasing, the only question is how fast. I think slower as oil wells and export terminals are still being rehabilitated and brought up to speed.

As a benchmark, Libya was producing 1500k b/d in 2013. According to p. 54 of the August 2017 OPEC report, based on secondary sources (no primary data available), Libya averaged of 360k b/d (thousand b/d) for the entire 2016. However, in Q4 2016, production began to ramp up quickly to 574k, 656k in Q1 2017, and 709k inQ2 2017. July 2017 est. is now 1001k. A 3rd order polynomial trend line based on this data suggests slightly more than 1400k b/d by Sep. 2017. I believe this is very achievable given the fact these are existing fields/wells that do not require exploration. Libya is currently excluded from OPEC production caps. I predict that it will take advantage of it and ramp up production as quickly as possible before the next OPEC meeting in November. However, given the current instability in the region, I am revising down my estimate somewhat. http://www.opec.org/opec_web/static_files_project/media/downloads/publications/OPEC%20MOMR%20August%202017.pdf

So many variables: potential OPEC caps, blockades, worker strikes, crumbling infrastructure, political infighting,  fractious militias... seems the Libyan oil czar is holding coalition of producers together by duck tape, toothpicks and the promise of parks and school. Since the data isn't all that helpful for projections, I sourced production estimates and ran a couple scenarios based on end of year targets. I also looked, but didn't deeply evaluate, production from different oil fields to see if the risks were unevenly distributed. I erred on the low side due to risk factors listed above. The probabilities are a bit more intuitive than I am comfortable with.

During this month (August 2017) oil production in Libya has increased due the following:  al-Shuaib oil refinery has increased its oil production; a larger problem which resulted in an increase is the problematic ineffectiveness of the OPEC cuts; the main causal factors determinant is the increased production not only in Libya but also Nigeria.  The strategic interactions among these two oil producing nations also contribute to the lack of effective commitment to the production cuts.   This interaction causes other freerider oil producers to forge a similar path.
If the short term trend continue we should be somewhere around 1100.
